e. Five-Year Accident History

Evonik has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past 5 years. There have been no incidents in the last five years that meet the RMP reporting requirements.

f. Emergency Response Program Information 

The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid, medical treatment, evacuation plans, and notification of local emergency response. 

The overall emergency response program for Evonik is coordinated with the Mobile Fire Department and the Emergency Management Agency (EMA). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the Local Emergency Planning Committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. 

Evonik maintains 24/7 communication capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, Evonik conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the plant provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the plant.

g. Planned Changes To Improve Safety

Evonik resolves all findings from process hazard analysis, some of which result in modifications to the process. The following types of changes are planned: incre

a. Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

Evonik Corporation has a standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of chemical processes. Evonik's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

b. General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The prevention program used by the facility is consistent with the Occupational, Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management Standard. The standard includes management systems elements involving safety information, hazard evaluations, operating procedures, employee training, contractor programs, mechanical integrity, pre-start up safety reviews, incident investigations, safe work practices and emergency response. There are a number of chemical specific prevention steps used at the facility including release detection equipment, release containment, and release control equipment. The accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards of chemicals that are posed to employees, the public, and the environment by maintaining a written emergency response and contingency program that comprehensively describes the emergency response program for Evonik Corporation.

c. Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

Evonik Corp Mobile Facility is located in the Theodore Industrial Park in Theodore, Alabama on a 753-acre site. This facility has 761 employees. There are multiple production areas that produce products in a continuous production schedule, operating 24 hours per day, 7 days a week.
